A series of Co-doped cryptomelane (OMS-2) catalysts with different Co/Mn molar ratios were synthesized by a one-step redox method, and used for CO preferential oxidation in H2-rich streams. Among them, the Co0.3 OMS-2 catalyst exhibited the best catalytic performance, the CO conversion rate of nearly 100 % at 110 °C and maintaining for at least 100 h. The characterization results indicated that the Co ions synergistically replaced the Mn and K sites, enhancing the dissociation of the Mn-O bonds through oxygen vacancy engineering, and more oxygen vacancies promoted the improvement of the redox performance of the Co0.3 OMS-2 catalyst. By synchronously regulating the surface alkalinity, the desorption of the reaction product CO2 was enhanced. This structure-performance correlation mechanism breaks through the thermodynamic limitations of traditional metal-supported OMS-2 catalysts and provides a new idea for the design of efficient CO preferential oxidation catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords OMS-2 Cobalt doping Oxygen vacancy CO preferential oxidation Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction With the rapid development of social economy, large-scale exploitation of fossil fuels has led to a sharp deterioration of the ecological environment, and energy shortage and global warming have constituted a dual development crisis. Based on the strategic dimension of sustainable development, China has actively responded to the global trend of low-carbon transition, and scientifically established a phased policy goal system of “carbon peak” and “carbon neutrality” [1,2]. Hydrogen energy, as a clean and renewable secondary energy source, provides a sustainable solution for controlling greenhouse effect and alleviating energy shortage [3]. Proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) can realize efficient utilization of hydrogen energy. The battery can now be widely used in vehicles such as cars and ships, allowing them to achieve zero-emission operation. And its advantages include efficient energy conversion, low operating temperature (80 °C-200 °C) and environmental friendliness [4]. At present, the main sources of hydrogen include hydrocarbon or alcohol reforming, water-gas conversion reactions. However, there are inevitably trace amounts of CO in the reaction products, and the residual CO in the hydrogen-rich atmosphere can lead to platinum anode poisoning of PEMFCs, and even deactivation. Therefore, CO must be effectively removed to trace levels (< 10 ppm) to ensure the normal operation of PEMFCs [5]. In recent years, catalysts including noble and non-noble metal oxides have been widely used in the study of CO-PROX. Among them, Pd, Pt, Au and other precious metal catalysts have been considered to be the first choice, which can achieve 100 % CO conversion at relatively low temperatures [6–11]. However, the high cost of precious metals limit their practical applications, and the CO2 selectivity of precious metals decreases rapidly at higher temperatures due to the competitive oxidation of H2, which has promoted the development of a large number of economically viable non-precious metal oxide catalysts, such as CeO2, MnO2, CoOx, and oxide composites. As previously reported in the literatures, they have excellent CO-PROX catalytic properties [12–15]. Among them, CuO/CeO2 has comparable catalytic performance to precious metal catalyst, However, with the increase of reaction temperature, Cu0 produced on CuO/CeO2 catalyst will preferentially oxidize H2 to produce H2O, resulting in a decrease in CO2 selectivity [16–19]. It is well known that Co3O4 exhibits outstanding catalytic performance for CO oxidation especially at very low temperature (as low as −77 °C) [20–22]. Furthermore, Co3O4 with specific morphology or deposited on suitable carriers showed good catalytic activity against CO-PROX [23,24]. However, in the Co3O4 catalytic system, the H2 molecules in the feed gas first undergo oxidation reactions to generate H2O, while the catalyst surface undergoes reduction reactions, where Co3+ is reduced to the metal state of Co(Co0). These reduced metal sites act as active centers, further catalyzing the methanation reaction of CO to produce CH4, resulting in irreversible consumption of the effective H2 in the feed gas. It is noteworthy that the H2O molecules occupy the surface active oxygen vacancies, thereby reducing the reduction efficiency of Co3+/Co2+. This surface adsorption competition mechanism not only affects the stability of the catalytic CO oxidation cycle but also leads to a significant reduction in the selectivity of the target product [4,25,26]. Among these non-precious metal oxide catalysts, cryptomelane (OMS-2), an effective manganese oxide catalyst, belongs to the α-MnO2 crystalline form, which is a pore structure of 2 × 2 chains constructed by octahedral [MnO6] units connected through oxygen atoms at the octahedral vertices, the K + and H2O in the pores act to maintain charge balance and stabilize the structure [27,28]. OMS-2, with its unique tunnel-shaped porous structure and the mixed valence state characteristics of manganese (Mn2+/Mn3+/Mn4+ reversible redox system), demonstrates significant advantages in the field of environmental catalysis. This material has successfully been applied in the following environmental purification areas through the efficient catalytic action of surface active oxygen species: deep oxidation and degradation of water pollutants [29,30]; high-value conversion of biomass resources [31,34]; and treatment of gaseous pollutants (covering catalytic combustion of volatile organic compounds (VOCs), ozone decomposition, and low-temperature oxidation of carbon monoxide, etc.) [32–35]. It is reported that there exists a significant structure-activity relationship between the catalytic activity of OMS-2 catalyst materials and the concentration of their oxygen vacancy (Ov) as well as their redox properties [36]. Dong et al. [37] reported the 5 %Fe/OMS-2 sample prepared by doping and reflux method has good catalytic CO oxidation performance, and the CO conversion rate can reach 90 % at 160 °C, and the high migration capacity of lattice oxygen is conducive to its good low-temperature reduction performance. Dang et al. [38] in our research group found that the CuO/OMS-2 after acid treatment formed more oxygen vacancies due to the decrease in K + content, and the increase in bronsted acid sites favored CO2 desorption. This leads to the release of more active sites and facilitates the CO-PROX reaction. Hu et al. [39] found that 5 %Ag/OMS-2 catalysts has excellent CO-PROX performance, and the specific surface area and redox capacity of the catalysts are the important factors affecting their activities. However, the catalytic activity decreased at higher temperatures, mainly due to the formation of Ag2O species will destroy part of the structure of OMS-2. Pahalagedara et al. [40] studied the low temperature oxidation of CO by different metal doping OMS-2. The results show that the Ni-K-OMS-2 material synthesized by microwave assisted hydrothermal synthesis has excellent structural oxygen migration and reversibility, and greatly reduces the activation energy of CO oxidation reaction. Yang et al. [41] synthesized Co-OMS-2 by hydrothermal method, and found its excellent performance in catalyzing CO oxidation was due to the high specific surface area, high active oxygen mobility and enhanced redox ability of catalyst. Dang et al. [42] synthesized a series of Cox-OMS-2 catalysts by sol-gel method. The study found that after doping Co, the active sites of the catalyst were Mn-VO Co structure. Meanwhile, the generation of oxygen vacancies was reduced, which promoted the electron transfer between oxygen vacancies and N2O molecules, thereby facilitating the catalytic decomposition of N2O. On this basis, Liu et al. [43] successfully anchored Co3O4 on the surface of different phases of MnO2 and constructed different Co3O4−MnO2 interfaces. Compared with β-MnO2, the catalytic activity of Co3O4/α-MnO2 and Co3O4/γ-MnO2 was significantly enhanced. This was because the oxygen vacancy content of Co3O4/α-MnO2 catalyst was significantly increased, thereby improving its redox performance and lattice oxygen migration rate, and greatly enhancing the catalytic ability for toluene oxidation. Yu et al. [44] reported a high-performance manganese-cobalt spinel oxide MnCoOx catalyst prepared by a layered double hydroxide (LDH) template method. The optimized MnCoOx-300 catalyst exhibited excellent CO preferential oxidation performance (80 °C-200 °C) under a high space velocity of 80,000 h-1. This outstanding activity stems from the abundant Mn3+/Co2+ redox pairs on the catalyst surface and the efficient synergy between lattice oxygen and adsorbed oxygen species. Currently, this performance surpasses that of previously reported non-precious metal catalysts, but the MnCoOx-300 catalyst shows slight deactivation after continuous operation for 60 h. Therefore, cobalt-doped OMS-2 exhibits excellent catalytic performance in reactions such as carbon monoxide oxidation, toluene oxidation, and N2O decomposition, and particularly has outstanding water resistance. However, for the CO-PROX reaction, Co doping on OMS-2 catalysts has been rarely reported. In this work, cobalt-manganese catalysts Cox-OMS-2 with different Co/Mn molar ratios (0, 0.1, 0.3, and 0.5, respectively) were prepared by redox method, and their catalytic performance for CO-PROX under hydrogen-rich atmosphere was investigated. OMS-2 and Co3O4 catalysts prepared by the same method were evaluated and compared, which enriched the design of high performance CO-PROX catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The OMS-2 sample was prepared by a simple redox method. Firstly, 6.32 g KMnO4 was added into 400 mL of deionized water, and after stirring for 10 min, the solution turned purple-red. Then the solution was heated in a water bath at 40 °C and 1.56 g of C2H2O4 (oxalic acid) was added, and the solution turned brown with the reaction for 30 min. Continue heating to 90 °C and stirring for 30 min (520 rmp). The mixture is dried to obtain a solid black substance. Finally, the OMS-2 catalyst was obtained after calcination at 450 °C for 2 h. Co-doped OMS-2 samples were synthesized by a very similar approach. The difference is that a certain amount of Co(NO3)2·6H2O powder and 1.56 g of oxalic acid were added to the beaker at the same time. The remaining steps are the same as the preparation of OMS-2. The obtained samples were named Cox-OMS-2 (where x is different Co/Mn molar ratio, x = 0.1, 0.3, 0.5). Co3O4 sample was prepared in a similar way. Firstly, 10.77 g of citric acid and 10.88 g of Co(NO3)2·6H2O were added to 75 mL of distilled water. It is then vigorously stirred at 40 °C for 0.5 h (520 rmp) to dissolve completely. The temperature is then raised to 90 °C, stirring and removing water through evaporation until a viscous substance is formed. The subsequent drying and roasting processes were consistent with the preparation of OMS-2. 2.2 Catalyst characterization and catalytic performance test In this work, the phase structure and properties of the catalyst were studied by XRF, XRD, FTIR, Raman and H2-TPR. For more details on characterization techniques, see supplementary material. 3 Results 3.1 Catalytic performance The comparison of catalyst activity is shown in Fig. 1 a and Fig. 1b Among the prepared samples, the Co0.3 OMS-2 sample has the best CO-PROX performance. At 110 °C (without water vapor) and 120 °C (3.3 % of water vapor), the conversion rate of CO can reach 100 %. In contrast, the CO conversion of the OMS-2 sample was only 49 % (without water vapor) and 39 % (3.3 % of water vapor) at 200 °C, respectively. It was also found that the CO conversion of the sample was reduced in the presence of water vapor, due to the competitive adsorption of water molecules on the sample surface [45]. Furthermore, as the reaction temperature increases, the CO2 selectivity of the Cox-OMS-2 catalyst gradually decreases under the condition of 3.3 % water vapor (Fig. 1c), and eventually stabilizes at 50 %. The CO2 selectivity of OMS-2 decreases to around 20 %. Combined with Fig. S2, it shows a similar trend for the CO2 selectivity of the Cox-OMS-2 catalyst under the condition of no water vapor, and this may be due to the reaction between hydrogen and oxygen at high temperatures. As can be seen from Fig. 1d, in the catalytic stability test of Co0.3 OMS-2 sample for CO-PROX reaction at 110 °C, the CO conversion rate can reach almost 100 % in the presence of 3.3 % water vapor, and the selectivity is basically maintained at about 50 % for at least 100 h. The CO-PROX catalytic activity and selectivity of the Co0.3 OMS-2 sample under different GHSV (as shown in Fig. S3) were compared with those of other catalysts reported in the literatures. The results are summarized in Table S1. Based on the data under different reaction conditions, although it is difficult to make an accurate comparison among these catalysts, it can still be observed that Co0.3 OMS-2 is a highly efficient CO-PROX catalyst. 3.2 XRF XRF was used to detect the elemental composition of OMS-2 and Cox-OMS-2 catalysts, and the results were shown in Table S2. For the synthesized Cox-OMS-2 sample, the actual Co/Mn molar ratio determined by XRF is basically close to the theoretical value. Meanwhile, as can be seen from Table S2, the weight ratio of K/(K+Mn+Co) on the surface of the Cox-OMS-2 sample measured by XRF and XPS decreases as the molar ratio of Co/Mn increases. The measured weight ratio of K/(K+Mn+Co) is smaller than the actual value of K/(K+Mn) of the pure OMS-2 sample. In addition, compared with the actual Mn/(K+Mn) value of pure OMS-2 sample measured by XRF (0.79), The Mn/(K+Co+Mn) weight ratio of Co0.1 OMS-2 (0.73), Co0.3 OMS-2 (0.65) and Co0.5 OMS-2 (0.60) decreased slightly. 3.3 Phase structure and morphology Fig. 2 a shows the X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns of the OMS-2 and Cox-OMS-2 samples. It is observed that the peaks of the Cox-OMS-2 sample are located at 2θ = 12.8°, 18.1°, 28.7°, 37.6°, 42.0°, 49.8°, and 60.0°, which belongs to the OMS-2 (110), (200), (310), (211), (301), (411), and (521) crystal faces [44]. In the Fig. 2a, only diffraction peaks representing the structure of OMS-2 were visible, and no characteristic peaks of Co oxides or salts were detected. This indicates that Co ions are doped in the structure of OMS-2 and/or dispersed over the OMS-2 surface [46]. Fig. 2b also shows a localized magnified view of the crystalline peak (211) at 2θ = 37.6° for the Cox-OMS-2 catalyst. It is noteworthy that the diffraction peak is slightly shifted to an angle (from 37.6° of OMS-2 to 37.8° of Co0.3 OMS-2). The actual radius of Mn3+ (66 pm) and Co3+ (63 pm), which suggests that Co3+ has been doped into the OMS-2 lattice, replacing the Mn3+ in the framework, thus inducing the lattice contraction [47]. In contrast, Co0.5 OMS-2 shows an inverse shift of the peak to a lower angle, which may be due to the fact that with the increase of Co content, lots of Co ions were distributed between OMS-2 layers, resulting in a significant excess of Co ions in OMS-2 pores, although the radius of K ions was larger than that of Co ions. However, high concentrations of Co ions still lead to a slight expansion of the OMS-2 lattice. In addition, the diffraction peak at 36.9° of the Co0.5 OMS-2 sample can be attributed to the (311) crystal plane of Co3O4, and it slightly overlaps with the diffraction peak of OMS-2 on the (211) crystal plane [48,49]. At the same time, the average crystallite size of OMS-2, Co0.1 OMS-2, Co0.3 OMS-2 and Co0.5 OMS-2 catalysts prepared by Scherrer equation were calculated to be 11, 24, 35 and 27 nm, respectively. It can be seen that Co doping does not obviously change the crystal phase type of OMS-2, but changes the crystallite size. Fig. 3 a shows the FT-IR spectral information of the OMS-2 and Cox-OMS-2 samples with absorption bands at 475, 530, 580, 738, 1632 and 3440 cm-1, indicating that all samples have a good OMS-2 structure [50]. The 738, 580, 530 and 475 cm-1 bands can be ascribed to the vibrations of Mn-O bonds [51]. Among these bands, the 738 cm-1 is the Mn-O-Mn bridging oxygen bond vibrational absorption of the OMS-2. The infrared peaks of 1632 cm-1 and 3440 cm-1 belongs to bending and stretching vibrations of -OH respectively [52–54]. Compared with other catalysts, Co0.5 OMS-2 detected an additional band at 665 cm-1, which can be attributed to the stretching vibration of the Co-O bond. This is due to the large amount of Co doping, which forms a small amount of Co3O4 on the surface of the catalyst [55], which was also observed in TEM. The Cox-OMS-2 samples showed significantly weaker absorption band intensities at 580, 530, and 475 cm-1 than that of OMS-2, which may be caused by partial substitution of Mn by Co. At the same time, Co doping OMS-2 causes the redshift of 738 cm-1 band (from 738 to 723 cm-1). According to Eq. (3.1), where σ is the vibrational frequency, k is the chemical bonding constant, and μ is the effective relative atomic mass. The redshift is due to the decrease of the k, that is the Mn-O bond becomes weaker [56]. Therefore, Co doping can weaken the Mn-O bond strength and make oxygen more active, which is conducive to the migration of surface reactive oxygen species. Based on the spectral data in the 1632 cm-1 band, the peak areas were integrated to further compare the number of surface hydroxyl groups in the prepared catalysts. As shown in Fig. S5, the peak areas of surface hydroxyl groups decreased in the following order: Co0.5 OMS-2 > Co0.1 OMS-2 > Co0.3 OMS-2 > OMS-2. This indicates that the content of hydroxyl groups on the surface of Co0.3 OMS-2 catalyst or the physical adsorption of water is lower than that of Co0.1 OMS-2, thus having excellent water resistance [17]. This is also verified by the Raman shown in Fig. 3b The OMS-2 catalyst showed significant Raman peaks at 185 cm-1, 576 cm-1 and 637 cm-1, indicating the formation of a 2 × 2 tunnel structure of the OMS-2 octahedron [MnO6]. Among them, 185 cm-1 vibration peaks are attributed to the deformation vibration mode of Mn-O-Mn bond. The Raman peaks at 576 cm-1 and 637 cm-1 are attributed to the vibration modes of the Mn-O bond along the direction parallel to and perpendicular to the [MnO6] octahedral double chain, respectively [47]. The results show that the Raman peak intensity at 637 cm-1 decreases with the increase of Co doping, and there is a slight redshift (from 640 cm-1 at OMS-2 to 633 cm-1 at Co0.5 OMS-2). The results showed that Co ions successfully entered the lattice structure of OMS-2 and effectively weakens the strength of Mn-O bond, making oxygen atoms more easily released. (3.1) k / μ /2 π Fig. 4 a shows that the N2 physical adsorption-desorption isotherm is a type IV adsorption isotherm and the H3 hysteresis loop, indicating that there are typical mesoporous structures in OMS-2 and Cox-OMS-2 samples [57]. The pore size distribution of each catalyst is shown in Fig. 4b The pore size distribution peak is mainly concentrated in the range of 5–45 nm, which accords with the main characteristics of mesoporous materials and is consistent with the characteristics of N2 physical adsorption-desorption isotherm. OMS-2 shows a single peak at 20 nm, and the main aperture distribution is 10–40 nm. In addition, the pore size distribution of Co0.1 OMS-2 samples is unimodal at 5–10 nm, and the pore size distribution of Co0.3 OMS-2 samples is very close to that of OMS-2, but a new peak appears at 67 nm. Co0.5 OMS-2 showed a four-peak porous distribution at 3, 5, 12 and 20 nm, respectively, which may be due to the fact that with the increase of Co content, Mn and K ions in the lattice structure were replaced, resulting in the porous characteristics of Co0.5 OMS-2 samples. Table S3 shows the specific surface area, pore volume and average pore size of Co3O4, OMS-2 and Cox-OMS-2 catalysts. With the increase of Co doping, the specific surface area of these samples gradually increases, and the pore size gradually decreases. The increase of the specific surface area of the samples is related to the increase of the pore number, which can be seen from the results of the pore size distribution. As shown in Fig. 5 TEM and HRTEM, the rod-like morphology of OMS-2 is almost unchanged after Co doping. TEM images of OMS-2 (Fig. 5b) show that the spacing of 0.49 and 0.68 is related to the (200) and (110) crystal planes of OMS-2, respectively [58]. At the same time, clear lattice fringes were observed on OMS-2, indicating good crystallinity. Comparatively, the lattice stripes of Co0.3 OMS-2 (Fig. 5f) become blurred and curved, indicating more defects on its surface. However, many small nanoparticles were observed attached to the surface of Co0.5 OMS-2 nanorods (Fig. 5g), presumably due to the fact that the excess Co doping attached to the sample surface. As shown in Fig. S4(a), the Co3O4 nanoparticles are spherically aggregated. The lattice spacing of 0.46 nm and 0.28 nm observed in Fig. S4(b) are attributed to the (111) and (220) crystal faces of Co3O4, respectively [55]. Meanwhile, it can be seen from Fig. S4(c)-(g) that the doped Co substance is highly dispersed on the surface of the OMS-2 sample. 3.4 H2-TPR Fig. 6 shows the H2-TPR characteristics of OMS-2 and Cox-OMS-2 catalysts. For Cox-OMS-2 catalysts, the reduction process can be decomposed into four characteristic peaks: α peak at low temperature (250–300 °C) corresponds to the reduction of surface adsorbed oxygen species; β peak (300–350 °C) reflects the phase transition from MnO2 to Mn2O3. The γ peak (350–400 °C) includes the reduction of Mn2O3 to Mn3O4 and the valence transition of Co3+ to Co2+. The δ peak at high temperature (400–450 °C) corresponds to the further reduction of Mn3O4 to MnO and the reduction of Co2+ to metallic Co0 [55,59]. For pure OMS-2 samples, the distribution of the four reduction peaks is relatively concentrated. However, with the increase of Co doping, the reduction peak showed a tendency to move towards low temperature, which may be related to the good synergistic effect between Co and OMS-2 [41]. Compared with pure OMS-2, the reduction peak temperature of Co0.3 OMS-2 and Co0.5 OMS-2 samples moved significantly towards low temperature, indicating that Co0.3 OMS-2 and Co0.5 OMS-2 samples were easier to reduce. Table 1 lists the hydrogen consumption corresponding to the reduction peaks of the four catalysts. With the increase of Co doping, the total hydrogen consumption gradually increases, indicating that Co doping is conducive to improving the reduction capacity of OMS-2. In terms of α peak, Co0.3 OMS-2 has the highest α peak hydrogen consumption (2802 µmol·g-1) and the lowest reduction temperature (256 °C). At the same time, compared with Co0.3 OMS-2, the β and γ reduction peak temperatures of Co0.5 OMS-2 samples were further reduced, but the α peak temperature was slightly higher (260 °C) and the hydrogen consumption (2524 µmol·g-1) was also reduced. Lower initial reduction temperature indicates that surface adsorptive oxygen has higher redox performance and reactivity [50]. Therefore, compared with OMS-2 and other Cox-OMS-2 catalysts, Co0.3 OMS-2 not only has the most surface oxygen species, but also has a lower reduction temperature, showing excellent redox reduction properties. 3.5 CO2-TPD The CO2-TPD results for the catalysts are shown in Fig. 7 a, with two CO2 desorption peaks in the range of 50–350 °C. The desorption peaks at <150 °C and 150–350 °C correspond to the desorption of CO2 on weak, medium-strength basic sites, respectively [60]. As can be seen from Fig. 7b, compared with the OMS-2 sample (122 °C), the desorption peak of Cox-OMS-2 sample at the weakly alkaline site moves to the low temperature, and the desorption temperature of Co0.5 OMS-2 is the lowest (100 °C), indicating that the strength of the weakly alkaline site on the catalyst surface is weakened after the addition of Co. In addition, it can be seen from Table 2 that with the increase of Co doping, the number of weakly basic sites decreases. Therefore, the moderate amount of Co doping weakened the surface alkalinity of OMS-2 and facilitated the desorption of the acidic product CO2 [61]. 3.6 EPR In order to further demonstrate the concentration of oxygen vacancies in the samples, EPR test was performed. As shown in Fig. 8 , the intensity of the signal peak observed at g = 2.004 directly reflects the amount of oxygen vacancies in the catalyst [38]. Among them, Co0.3 OMS-2 has the highest content of oxygen vacancies, while Co0.5 OMS-2 is close to that of Co0.1 OMS-2. This suggests that the introduction of appropriate amount of cobalt favors the formation of oxygen vacancies on the surface of the OMS-2 catalyst. However, since the excess Co doping could not enter into the OMS-2 structure and attached to the surface of the Co0.5 OMS-2 samples, this could be the reason for the decrease in its OV content, which was also verified in the TEM. 3.7 XPS Fig. 9 shows the XPS spectrum used to analyze the surface composition of the samples. According to the Fig. 8a, two signals at 642.0 and 653.0 eV are attributed to Mn 2p3/2 and Mn 2p1/2 states, respectively. In the Mn 2p1/2 XPS spectra, the four samples with peaks near 652.8 (Mn3+) and 654.7 eV (Mn4+), respectively [50]. With increasing Co doping, the Mn 2p peak of the Co0.5 OMS-2 sample is at 642.4 eV, which is shifted towards higher binding energy by 0.3 eV compared to the OMS-2 (642.1 eV) peak position. It is shown that Co doping affects its surface elemental content. The quantitative results (Table 3 ) show that the ratio of Mn3+/Mn3++Mn4+ on Co0.3 OMS-2 (67.19 %) is higher than that on Co0.5 OMS-2 (65.88 %), Co0.1 OMS-2 (64.79 %), and OMS-2 (60.81 %). It is reported that an increase in the content of Mn3+ in OMS-2 is conducive to the formation of oxygen vacancies, which helps maintain charge balance [35]. At the same time, it can provide more sites for the activation of gaseous oxygen, thereby increasing the number of Oads [60,62,63]. As shown in the Mn 3 s (Fig. 9b) spectrum, the following formula can get the average oxidation state (AOS) of Mn: AOS = 8.956–1.126∆Es, and ∆Es is the difference between the binding energies of the two peaks in Mn 3 s. It is reported that a lower AOS value indicates a higher proportion of Mn3+ species in the catalytic material, which is closely related to the redox performance of the catalyst [32,57]. The calculation results (Table 3) demonstrate that the AOS value of Co0.3 OMS-2 is the lowest, at 3.439, indicating that the surface of Co0.3 OMS-2 contains more Mn3+ ions. The generation of Mn3+ is mainly attributed to the electron transfer from Co2+ to Mn4+ (Co2++Mn4+→Co3++Mn3+). Liu et al. [64]conducted research and found that at the interface of Co3O4−MnO2, an oxidation–reduction cycle was formed between Mn4+ and Co2+. The generation of Mn3+ was related to the electron transfer from Co2+ to Mn4+ at the interface, which was beneficial for enhancing the catalytic activity of toluene oxidation. Concerning the O 1 s XPS spectra (Fig. 9c), three peaks can be seen around 529.9 eV, 531.2 eV, and 532.4 eV, which can be related to surface lattice oxygen (Olatt), surface adsorbed oxygen species (Oads, including O2-, O2 2-, and O-), and surface physically adsorbed oxygen species (Ophy, including OH- and H2O), respectively [65]. Typically, gaseous O2 is adsorbed on OV on the surface of metal oxides to form Oads species, which is considered to play the most critical role in CO-PROX [45]. Therefore, the relative content of OV in the catalyst can be evaluated by comparing the ratio of Oads/Ophy+Oads+Olatt. The contents of Oads and Mn3+ show a “volcanic type” trend (Table 3), and on the surface of Co0.3 OMS-2, the contents of Oads (45.82 %) and Mn3+(67.19 %) are the highest. However, on the surface of Co0.5 OMS-2, the contents of Oads and Mn3+ decrease, being 44.23 % and 65.88 % respectively. The results indicate that there are more oxygen vacancies on the surface of Co0.3 OMS-2, which is consistent with the highest Mn3+ content reflected in the Mn 2p XPS spectrum of Co0.3 OMS-2. Moreover, the content of oxygen vacancies is the highest, which is consistent with the EPR conclusion [66]. In the Co 2p XPS spectra (Fig. 9d), the peaks of Co2p3/2 (780.0 eV) can be divided into two peaks around 782.5 eV (Co2+) and 780.4 eV (Co3+) [67]. Table 3 shows that as Co doping increases, the ratio of Co3+/(Co2++Co3+) gradually increases. 4 Discussions A series of Cox-OMS-2 catalysts with different Co/Mn molar ratios were synthesized by redox method. The effects of Co doping on the structure of OMS-2 and catalytic performance of CO-PROX were studied. The results show that adding appropriate amount of Co significantly improves the catalytic activity of OMS-2 catalyst, among which Co0.3 OMS-2 catalyst has the best catalytic performance. Under the condition of GHSV of 6000 h-1, When 1 % CO, 1 % O2, 50 % H2, N2 equilibrium gas and 3.3 % H2O coexist, the CO conversion rate on Co0.3 OMS-2 catalyst can reach 100 % at 110 °C, and the selectivity of CO2 is maintained at about 50 %, which can be maintained for at least 100 h. Through XRF and XRD characterization, it can be seen that Co ion partially replaces Mn ion in the OMS-2 lattice and a certain number of K ion in the pores. TEM (HRTEM) analysis showed that the lattice fringes of Co0.3 OMS-2 were fuzzy, the crystal structure was poor, and there were many defects, which indicated that there might be more oxygen vacancies on the surface of Co0.3 OMS-2 catalyst, which was also confirmed by EPR results. The XPS results show that the contents of Mn3+ and Oads in Cox-OMS-2 catalyst showed a “volcanic” growth trend. That is, Co0.3 OMS-2 > Co0.5 OMS-2 > Co0.1 OMS-2 > Co3O4 > OMS-2, which is also consistent with the results of reaction activity. Combined with EPR results, it was found that the surface oxygen vacancy content of Co0.3 OMS-2 was the highest. However, with the increase of Co content, the CO-PROX activity of Co0.5 OMS-2 catalyst decreased, which may be due to the addition of excess Co causing Co3O4 to adhere to the OMS-2 surface. Thus covering the oxygen vacancy on the surface of Co0.5 OMS-2. The Raman and FT-IR results show that Co doping weakens the strength of Mn-O bond and makes it easier to release oxygen atoms, thus generating more active sites, which is conducive to the adsorption and activation of CO and the generation of surface reactive oxygen species. Co0.3 OMS-2 has the most oxygen vacancies on the surface and has excellent redox performance. At the same time, CO2-TPD results showed that the number of weak alkaline sites on the surface of Co0.3 OMS-2 decreased, and the alkaline intensity decreased, which was conducive to CO2 desorption. Co was doped into the OMS-2 structure and promoted the formation of surface oxygen vacancies, which was verified by Raman and FT-IR spectroscopy. According to the literatures [59,68,69], in manganese oxides an increase in the concentration of surface oxygen vacancies and the capture of gaseous oxygen by the oxygen vacancies, results in the formation of adsorbed active oxygen species (O2- or O2 2-). These substances are more likely to be released and participate in the oxidation reaction process. The reaction rate can be increased at low temperatures (< 220 °C) through the Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism. The interaction between the adsorbed CO and the reactive oxygen species generates CO2, which is conducive to the progress of the CO-PROX reaction [45,70]. During this process, CO and oxygen are adsorbed at the manganese sites and the surface oxygen vacancies, respectively. Therefore, Cox-OMS-2 has excellent preferential oxidation catalytic performance for CO, and is a promising candidate material for developing effective manganese-based catalysts. 5 Conclusions In this study, a series of Cox-OMS-2 catalysts with different Co/Mn molar ratios were synthesized by redox method. The effects of Co doping on the structure of OMS-2 and catalytic performance of CO-PROX were studied. A series of characterization results showed that adding appropriate amount of Co significantly improved the catalytic activity of OMS-2 catalyst, among which Co0.3 OMS-2 (Co/Mn molar ratio = 0.3) had the best catalytic performance. Under the condition of GHSV of 6000 h-1, when 1 % CO, 1 % O2, 50 % H2, N2 equilibrium gas and 3.3 vol. % H2O coexist, and the reaction temperature is 110 °C, the CO conversion rate on Co0.3 OMS-2 catalyst can reach 100 %. The selectivity of CO2 is maintained at about 50 % and can be maintained for at least 100 h. A series of characterization results show that Co ions partially replace Mn ions in the OMS-2 lattice and a certain number of K ions in the pores. More importantly, there are more oxygen vacancies on the surface of Co0.3 OMS-2 catalyst, which is due to the fact that Co doping weakens the strength of Mn-O bond and makes oxygen atoms more easily released, thus generating more active sites. It is conducive to the adsorption and activation of CO. At the same time, more oxygen vacancies improved the redox performance of Co0.3 OMS-2 catalyst. In addition, CO2-TPD results showed that the number of weak alkaline sites on the surface of Co0.3 OMS-2 decreased, and the alkaline intensity decreased, which was conducive to the desorption of CO2. Therefore, Co0.3 OMS-2 has excellent CO-PROX catalytic performance. coredata.dc:description: A series of Co-doped cryptomelane (OMS-2) catalysts with different Co/Mn molar ratios were synthesized by a one-step redox method, and used for CO preferential oxidation in H2-rich streams. Among them, the Co0.3 OMS-2 catalyst exhibited the best catalytic performance, the CO conversion rate of nearly 100 % at 110 °C and maintaining for at least 100 h. The characterization results indicated that the Co ions synergistically replaced the Mn and K sites, enhancing the dissociation of the Mn-O bonds through oxygen vacancy engineering, and more oxygen vacancies promoted the improvement of the redox performance of the Co0.3 OMS-2 catalyst. By synchronously regulating the surface alkalinity, the desorption of the reaction product CO2 was enhanced. This structure-performance correlation mechanism breaks through the thermodynamic limitations of traditional metal-supported OMS-2 catalysts and provides a new idea for the design of efficient CO preferential oxidation catalysts.
